messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 17, 2019 - April 23, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-24T16:56:14Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-04-17T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-04-23T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190424-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-04-17.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2019-04-17. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-04-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-04-30T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be very low for the upcoming week.  There are no active regions currently visible at the available imagery of the sun's surface.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-04-25. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, STEREO B)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-22T22:51:11Z
## Message ID: 20190422-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by SOHO.

Start time of the event: 2019-04-22T03:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~434 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 26 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 87/9 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2019-04-22T03:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow) and STEREO B (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2019-04-23T18:00Z and STEREO B at 2019-04-25T16:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2019-04-22T03:36:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190422_114900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_PSP_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME was very difficult to measure, and these estimates are based upon rough measurements using data only from the LASCO C2 coronagraph difference imaging. The CME was too faint to appear in LASCO C3 difference imaging and a data gap prevents potential viewing of the CME in the STA Cor2 coronagraph at this time.

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, STEREO B)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-20T14:44:35Z
## Message ID: 20190420-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2019-04-20T01:25Z.

Estimated speed: ~387 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 30 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 90/2 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2019-04-20T01:25:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Parker Solar Probe and STEREO B.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2019-04-21T19:09Z and STEREO B at 2019-04-24T11:20Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2019-04-20T01:25:00-CME-001):

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 10, 2019 - April 16, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-17T19:37:15Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-04-10T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-04-16T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190417-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-04-10T00:00Z-06:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a weak coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2019-04-08. The solar wind speed reached values of ~480 km/s on 2019-04-10.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated up to ~90k pfu starting on 2019-04-11 due to the coronal hole described above, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-04-17T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-04-23T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There is currently only one active region visible on the solar surface that has potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 03, 2019 - April 09, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-10T21:11:23Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-04-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-04-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190410-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There was 1 C-type CME (see details below). Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that this CME (starting at 2019-04-03T04:09Z) may impact Spitzer at around 2019-04-05T22:20Z (plus minus 7 hours) and may have a flank impact at STEREO A at around 2019-04-06T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20190404-AL-001). This CME arrival was possibly detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments at around 2019-04-05T11:00Z.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-04-03T03:00Z-06:00Z, 2019-04-08T03:00Z-06:00Z and 2019-04-09T00:00Z-03:00Z. These slight increases in geomagnetic activity were associated with the arrival of two small coronal hole high speed streams detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2019-04-04 and 2019-04-08, respectively. The solar wind speed reached values of ~530 km/s on 2019-04-05 and ~480 km/s on 2019-05-08.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-04-05T15:30Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES are associated with the coronal hole high speed stream on 2019-04-04 described above (see notifications 20190405-AL-002 and 20190407-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2019-04-03T04:09Z     ~506            C              -124/3                 22                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-04-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-04-16T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are currently two active regions present on the visible solar disk that may have potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-07T15:59:58Z
## Message ID: 20190407-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDS 20190405-AL-001 and 20190405-AL-002. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes continue in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded the threshold of 10^5 pfu at 2019-04-05T15:30Z. The electron flux has continued to cross the threshold, with the latest crossing at 2019-04-06T08:25Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2019-04-04T12:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-04-05T15:30:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-05T16:03:12Z
## Message ID: 20190405-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-04-05T15:30Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2019-04-04T12:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-04-05T15:30:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-04T18:09:01Z
## Message ID: 20190404-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2019-04-03T04:09Z.

Estimated speed: ~506 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 22 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -124/3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2019-04-03T04:09:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2019-04-05T22:20Z and STEREO A at 2019-04-06T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2019-04-03T04:09:00-CME-001):

C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s

ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 27, 2019 - April 02, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-04-03T17:41:45Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-03-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-04-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190403-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.  
   
Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods 2019-03-31T03:00Z-06:00Z and 2019-04-01T09:00Z-12:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a weak coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2019-03-31. The solar wind speed reached values of ~400 km/s on 2019-03-31 and 2019-04-01.

The STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-03-28.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~550km/s on 2019-03-30.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-04-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-04-09T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are currently two active regions present on the visible solar surface that have potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-04-05.

R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
